title: Festive Apple Dip
instructions: Combine cream cheese, peanut butter, brown sugar, and vanilla in a bowl.
Mix with a hand mixer until smooth and well blended.
Transfer to serving dish and sprinkle with crushed peanuts.
notes: Best served chilled with apple slices.

title: Feyereisen Chocolate Chip Cookies
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Cream sugars and shortening together.
Add eggs and vanilla, mixing well.
Stir in salt, baking soda, and flour.
Fold in chocolate chips.
Drop spoonfuls onto greased baking sheet.
Bake for 8–10 minutes until lightly golden.

title: Mark’s Fudge
instructions: Combine butter, sugar, evaporated milk, and marshmallows in saucepan.
Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, for 5 minutes.
Remove from heat and stir in chocolate chips.
Pour into greased pan and allow to cool.
Cut into squares once firm.

title: Quiche
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F and prepare pie pan.
Sauté onion in olive oil until soft.
Add ham and garlic; cook 2 minutes.
Add broccoli and cook 2 minutes more.
Whisk eggs, cream, mustard, salt, and pepper.
Place vegetables in crust and sprinkle with cheese.
Pour egg mixture over filling.
Bake 40–45 minutes until set.
Cool 15 minutes before slicing.

title: Puppy Chow
instructions: Melt peanut butter, chocolate chips, and butter together.
Pour mixture over cereal and toss to coat.
Place coated cereal and powdered sugar in large bag.
Shake until evenly coated.
notes: Also known as Muddy Buddies.

title: Hot Chicken Salad
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Combine chicken, celery, onion, cheese, almonds, mayonnaise, and soup.
Spread 1 cup crushed chips in bottom of greased 9×13 pan.
Add chicken mixture to pan.
Top with remaining crushed chips.
Bake for 60 minutes until bubbly.
notes: Traditionally served with croissants.

title: Wild Rice Hot Dish (Robin’s)
instructions: Rinse wild rice thoroughly.
Combine rice, celery, water, and broth; boil for 30 minutes until tender.
Brown hamburger with onions in separate pan.
Combine rice mixture, meat, and soup.
Heat in oven at 250°F for 20 minutes or until warmed through.

title: Mark’s Chow Mein
instructions: Brown pork and onion together.
Boil celery until soft; reserve cooking water.
Add celery, reserved water, molasses, and soy sauce to pork.
Mix cornstarch and water; stir into mixture to thicken.
Add sugar to taste and heat through.
notes: Serve over rice or noodles.

title: Mark’s Meatloaf
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Brown hamburger and sausage.
Combine meat with crackers, milk, eggs, salt, and pepper.
Press mixture into meatloaf pan.
Mix brown sugar and ketchup; spread over top.
Bake for 1 hour 15 minutes.

title: Wren’s Bagel Dip
instructions: Combine mayonnaise and sour cream in a large bowl.
Stir in seasoning salt, dill weed, and parsley.
Fold in corned beef and onion if using.
Mix until evenly combined.
Chill before serving.
notes: Serve with sliced bagels. This recipe is often doubled for gatherings.

title: Wren’s Cuban Toasties
ingredients: 1½ oz boiled deli ham, finely chopped (about ⅓ cup)
3 oz shredded Swiss cheese (about ¾ cup)
instructions: Preheat oven to 500°F.
Mix ham, cheese, mayonnaise, onion, chili sauce, and mustard in a bowl.
Arrange baguette slices on foil-lined baking sheet.
Place pickle slices on each bread slice.
Spread ham mixture evenly on top.
Bake 8–10 minutes until golden and bubbly.
Cool slightly before serving.
notes: Recipe is typically doubled for parties.

title: Wren’s Salsa
instructions: Combine all ingredients except cornstarch and water in a large pot.
Simmer for 3–4 minutes.
Mix cornstarch with water to create a slurry.
Stir slurry into salsa to thicken.
Simmer briefly until desired consistency is reached.
notes: Seal in jars or freeze for later use.

title: Wren’s Taco Dip
instructions: Blend sour cream, cream cheese, and taco seasoning until smooth.
Spread mixture evenly onto serving platter.
Top with salsa, lettuce, and shredded cheese.
Chill briefly before serving.
notes: Serve with tortilla chips.

title: Mark’s Monster Bars
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper or grease lightly.
Cream brown sugar, white sugar, butter, and peanut butter until fluffy.
Beat in eggs and vanilla.
Stir in quick oats, old-fashioned oats, and baking soda.
Fold in M\&M’s and chocolate chips.
Press mixture evenly into prepared pan.
Bake for 17–20 minutes until edges are lightly browned.
Cool completely before cutting into bars.
notes: Bars will appear slightly underbaked in the center but will firm as they cool.

title: Wren’s Fruit Pizza
ingredients: 4 oz Cool Whip (or less, to taste)
Assorted fresh fruit (berries, kiwi, mandarin oranges, etc.)
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Press cookie dough evenly onto a pizza pan or baking sheet.
Bake for 10–12 minutes until lightly golden.
Cool completely.
Beat cream cheese until smooth.
Mix in sugar, then fold in Cool Whip.
Spread mixture over cooled crust.
Arrange fruit on top as desired.
notes: Chill before serving for best texture.

title: Quick & Easy Fudgy Brownies
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Melt butter and mix with sugar.
Beat in eggs one at a time.
Stir in cocoa powder, flour, and vanilla.
Spread batter into greased pan.
Bake 25–30 minutes or until set.

title: Raisin Cookies
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Cream butter and brown sugar.
Beat in egg and vanilla.
Mix in flour, baking soda, and salt.
Fold in raisins.
Drop spoonfuls onto greased baking sheet.
Bake 10–12 minutes until lightly browned.

title: Chicken Wild Rice Soup
ingredients: Salt and black pepper, to taste
instructions: Rinse wild rice thoroughly.
Combine rice, water, and broth; simmer 40–45 minutes until tender.
In a separate pot, melt butter and sauté onion, celery, and carrots until soft.
Stir in flour and cook 1 minute.
Gradually whisk in milk until smooth and thickened.
Add cooked rice and chicken.
Season with salt and pepper and heat through.
notes: Soup thickens as it cools; add broth when reheating if needed.

title: Sausage Skillet Supper
instructions: Heat olive oil in large skillet over medium heat.
Add sausage and cook until browned.
Add potatoes and cook until tender.
Stir in onion and green pepper.
Season with salt and pepper and cook until vegetables are soft.

title: Savory Chicken Squares
ingredients: 1 cup crushed stuffing mix or seasoned breadcrumbs
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Mix chicken, cream cheese, mayonnaise, and soup until combined.
Press one package of crescent dough into greased baking dish.
Spread chicken mixture evenly over dough.
Top with second package of dough.
Sprinkle with stuffing mix.
Bake 30–35 minutes until golden.

title: Stuffed Pepper Soup
instructions: Brown ground beef with onion.
Add green peppers and cook until slightly softened.
Stir in tomatoes and tomato sauce.
Simmer 20 minutes.
Add cooked rice and season with salt and pepper.
Heat through before serving.

title: Spinach Dip
ingredients: 1 package frozen chopped spinach, thawed and drained
instructions: Thaw spinach completely and squeeze out excess moisture.
Combine sour cream, mayonnaise, and vegetable soup mix.
Stir in spinach, water chestnuts, and green onions.
Mix until evenly combined.
Chill at least 1 hour before serving.
notes: Serve with bread cubes or fresh vegetables.

title: Broccoli Salad
ingredients: ½ cup red onion, finely diced
instructions: Combine broccoli, onion, cheese, and bacon in large bowl.
Whisk mayonnaise, vinegar, and sugar together.
Pour dressing over broccoli mixture.
Toss to coat evenly.
Chill before serving.

title: Cowboy Caviar
ingredients: 1 can black beans, rinsed and drained
1 can black-eyed peas, rinsed and drained
instructions: Combine beans, peas, corn, tomatoes, onion, and bell pepper.
Whisk olive oil and vinegar together.
Pour dressing over mixture and toss to combine.
Season with salt and pepper.
Chill before serving.
notes: Serve as a dip with tortilla chips or as a side salad.

title: Pretzel Salad
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Mix pretzels, melted butter, and sugar; press into baking dish.
Bake crust for 10 minutes; cool completely.
Beat cream cheese and sugar until smooth.
Fold in whipped topping and spread over crust.
Dissolve gelatin in boiling water; cool slightly.
Stir in strawberries and pour over cream layer.
Chill until set.
notes: Ensure cream layer fully seals crust to prevent sogginess.

title: Biscuits & Gravy
ingredients: Salt and black pepper, to taste
instructions: Cook sausage in a large skillet over medium heat until browned.
Sprinkle flour over sausage and stir to coat.
Cook 1–2 minutes to remove raw flour taste.
Gradually stir in milk.
Simmer until gravy thickens, stirring frequently.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve hot over biscuits.

title: Skinny Pancakes
instructions: Whisk flour, baking powder, and salt together.
In a separate bowl, whisk milk, egg, and melted butter.
Combine wet and dry ingredients until just mixed.
Heat lightly greased skillet over medium heat.
Pour batter onto skillet and cook until bubbles form.
Flip and cook until golden.
notes: Serve with fruit or syrup.

title: Egg Kaka
instructions: Whisk eggs, milk, salt, and pepper together.
Heat butter or oil in skillet over medium heat.
Pour egg mixture into skillet.
Cook gently, stirring occasionally, until eggs are just set.
notes: Simple family breakfast staple.

title: Sausage Egg & Cheese Breakfast Bake
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Brown sausage and drain excess grease.
Spread bread cubes in greased baking dish.
Top with sausage and cheese.
Whisk eggs, milk, salt, and pepper; pour over mixture.
Bake 40–45 minutes until set.
notes: Can be assembled the night before and baked in the morning.

title: Cinnamon Rolls
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm water and let stand 5 minutes.
Combine milk, sugar, melted butter, eggs, and salt.
Add yeast mixture and flour gradually to form soft dough.
Knead until smooth and elastic.
Let dough rise until doubled.
Roll dough into rectangle and spread with softened butter.
Sprinkle with brown sugar and cinnamon.
Roll up, slice, and place in greased pan.
Let rise again, then bake at 350°F for 25–30 minutes.
notes: Top with favorite icing or glaze.

title: Poppy Seed Bread
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Mix dry ingredients together in a large bowl.
Whisk eggs, oil, milk, and vanilla together.
Combine wet and dry ingredients until just mixed.
Pour batter into greased loaf pans.
Bake 50–60 minutes until toothpick comes out clean.

title: Banana Nut Bread
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Combine flour, baking soda, and salt.
Cream butter and sugar.
Beat in eggs and bananas.
Stir in dry ingredients and nuts.
Pour into greased loaf pan.
Bake 60 minutes until set.

title: Popovers
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F.
Whisk flour, milk, eggs, and salt until smooth.
Grease popover pan generously.
Fill cups halfway with batter.
Bake 20 minutes, then reduce heat to 350°F.
Bake an additional 15–20 minutes until puffed and golden.
notes: Do not open oven during baking.

title: Chocolate Chip Cookies
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Cream butter and sugars until light and fluffy.
Beat in eggs and vanilla.
Mix in flour, baking soda, and salt.
Fold in chocolate chips.
Drop spoonfuls onto greased baking sheets.
Bake 10–12 minutes until edges are lightly golden.

title: Congo Bars
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Mix melted butter and brown sugar.
Stir in eggs and vanilla.
Add flour, baking powder, and salt.
Fold in chocolate chips.
Spread batter in greased 9×13 pan.
Bake 25–30 minutes until set.

title: Monster Cookies
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Cream butter and sugars.
Beat in eggs and vanilla.
Mix in peanut butter.
Stir in oats and baking soda.
Fold in chocolate chips and M\&M’s.
Drop spoonfuls onto baking sheets.
Bake 10–12 minutes.

title: Peanut Butter Cookies
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Mix peanut butter, sugar, egg, and vanilla until smooth.
Roll dough into balls and place on baking sheet.
Flatten with fork in crisscross pattern.
Bake 8–10 minutes.
notes: Classic 3-ingredient base with optional vanilla.

title: Cranberry Cake
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Grease a 9-inch baking dish.
Spread cranberries evenly in the bottom of the dish.
Cream butter and sugar until light.
Beat in egg and vanilla.
Mix flour, baking powder, and salt.
Add dry ingredients alternately with milk.
Spread batter over cranberries.
Bake 40–45 minutes until golden.
notes: Serve warm with whipped cream or vanilla ice cream.

title: Rhubarb Crunch
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Combine rhubarb, sugar, and flour; spread in baking dish.
Mix oats, brown sugar, and melted butter.
Sprinkle oat mixture over rhubarb.
Bake 35–40 minutes until bubbly.

title: Sour Cream Rhubarb Dessert
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Combine rhubarb, sugar, and flour; place in baking dish.
Whisk sour cream, eggs, and vanilla; pour over rhubarb.
Mix brown sugar, butter, and flour to form topping.
Sprinkle topping over rhubarb mixture.
Bake 40–45 minutes until set.

title: Pumpkin Pie
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F.
Mix pumpkin, sugar, eggs, spices, salt, and milk.
Pour filling into pie crust.
Bake 15 minutes.
Reduce oven to 350°F and bake 40–45 minutes until set.
notes: Cool completely before slicing.

title: Barb’s Wild Rice Hotdish
ingredients: Salt and black pepper, to taste
instructions: Rinse wild rice thoroughly.
Cook rice in water until tender; drain excess liquid.
Brown ground beef with onion; season lightly.
Combine cooked rice, beef mixture, and soups.
Transfer to greased baking dish.
Bake at 350°F for 30–40 minutes until heated through.
notes: Freezes well and reheats easily.

title: Gladys Hotdish
instructions: Brown ground beef with onion; drain.
Stir in soups, vegetables, salt, and pepper.
Simmer until vegetables are heated through.
Serve over cooked noodles or rice.

title: Hearty Beef ’N’ Potato Casserole
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Brown ground beef with onion; drain.
Layer potatoes in greased casserole dish.
Top with beef mixture and soup.
Cover and bake 45 minutes.
Uncover, sprinkle with cheese, and bake 10 minutes more.

title: Tator Tot Hotdish
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F.
Brown ground beef; season with salt and pepper.
Mix beef with soup and vegetables.
Spread mixture in greased baking dish.
Arrange tater tots evenly on top.
Bake 30 minutes.
Sprinkle with cheese if using and bake 10 minutes more.
notes: A classic Midwest comfort dish.

title: Chicken Spaghetti
ingredients: Salt and black pepper, to taste
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Combine chicken, spaghetti, soups, cheese, and onion.
Season with salt and pepper.
Transfer to greased baking dish.
Bake 30–35 minutes until bubbly.

title: Easy Stew
ingredients: Salt and black pepper, to taste
instructions: Combine all ingredients in large pot.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat.
Simmer 1½–2 hours until meat is tender.
Season to taste before serving.
notes: Also works well in a slow cooker.

title: Mock Chili
instructions: Brown ground beef with onion; drain.
Add tomato soup, beans, and chili powder.
Simmer 20–30 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper.

title: Jalapeño Popper Dip
ingredients: ½ cup crushed crackers or breadcrumbs
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Mix cream cheese and mayonnaise until smooth.
Stir in cheddar, mozzarella, and jalapeños.
Spread mixture into greased baking dish.
Top with crushed crackers or breadcrumbs.
Bake 20–25 minutes until bubbly and lightly browned.
notes: Serve warm with chips or crackers.

title: Pizza Dip
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Spread cream cheese in bottom of baking dish.
Layer pizza sauce over cream cheese.
Sprinkle with mozzarella and pepperoni.
Season lightly with Italian seasoning.
Bake 20–25 minutes until melted and bubbly.

title: Shrimp Dip
instructions: Mix cream cheese and sour cream until smooth.
Fold in shrimp and lemon juice.
Season with salt and pepper.
Chill before serving.
notes: Serve with crackers or sliced vegetables.

title: Coleslaw Dressing
instructions: Whisk mayonnaise, vinegar, sugar, salt, and pepper until smooth.
Taste and adjust seasoning as desired.
notes: Toss with shredded cabbage and carrots just before serving.

title: Julie Tartar Sauce
instructions: Combine all ingredients in a small bowl.
Mix until smooth and well blended.
Chill before serving.
notes: Great with fish fry or seafood.

title: The World’s Best Hot Fudge Sauce
instructions: Melt butter in a saucepan over medium heat.
Stir in cocoa powder and sugar.
Gradually add evaporated milk, stirring constantly.
Bring to a gentle boil and cook 5 minutes.
Remove from heat and stir in vanilla.
notes: Serve warm over ice cream. Sauce thickens as it cools.

title: Glaze for Cinnamon Rolls
instructions: Whisk powdered sugar, milk, and vanilla until smooth.
Drizzle over warm cinnamon rolls.

title: Refrigerator Pickles
instructions: Combine vinegar, water, sugar, salt, dill seed, and mustard seed in saucepan.
Bring mixture to a boil, stirring until sugar dissolves.
Place cucumbers in a heatproof container.
Pour hot brine over cucumbers.
Cool completely, then refrigerate.
notes: Best after chilling at least 24 hours. Keeps refrigerated for several weeks.

title: Zucchini Jam
instructions: Combine zucchini, sugar, and pineapple in large pot.
Bring to a boil and cook 10 minutes.
Remove from heat and stir in gelatin until dissolved.
Pour into jars and allow to cool.
Refrigerate or freeze.
notes: Great on toast or biscuits.

title: Glazed “Green Chunk” Pickles
instructions: Combine all ingredients in a saucepan.
Bring to a boil, stirring frequently.
Simmer 5–10 minutes until glazed.
Cool completely before storing.
notes: A long-standing family favorite pickle recipe.

title: Crockpot Apple Butter
instructions: Place apples and all ingredients in slow cooker.
Cook on low 8–10 hours, stirring occasionally.
Blend until smooth using immersion blender.
Cool and store in jars.
notes: Freezes well and makes great gifts.

title: Fish Fry (Grandma & Grandpa’s)
instructions: Heat oil in deep skillet to 350°F.
Mix flour, salt, and pepper.
Dredge fish fillets in flour mixture.
Fry fish until golden brown and cooked through.
Drain on paper towels.
notes: Often served after fishing trips or on Fridays.

title: Mustard Marinated Steak
instructions: Whisk mustard, olive oil, garlic, salt, and pepper.
Coat steak evenly with marinade.
Marinate at least 2 hours or overnight.
Grill or pan-sear steak to desired doneness.
Rest 5 minutes before slicing.

title: Soy Chicken Wings
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Mix soy sauce, brown sugar, garlic, and ginger.
Toss wings in sauce.
Bake 45–50 minutes, turning once, until glazed and cooked through.

title: Orange Jello
instructions: Dissolve gelatin in boiling water.
Stir in cold water.
Pour into dish and refrigerate until set.
notes: Classic simple dessert.

title: Jello Salad
instructions: Dissolve gelatin in boiling water.
Stir in cold water.
Fold in fruit or marshmallows.
Chill until set.

title: Winter Salad
instructions: Combine apples, celery, and walnuts.
Mix mayonnaise and lemon juice.
Toss salad with dressing.
Chill before serving.

title: Chocolate Martini
instructions: Combine ingredients in shaker with ice.
Shake until chilled.
Strain into martini glass.

title: White Russian Pudding Shots
instructions: Whisk pudding mix and milk until thick.
Stir in vodka and coffee liqueur.
Spoon into small cups.
Chill until set.

Top with whipped cream. Family Food History Schafer / Oehler Family Food History By Julie Joy Schafer Johnson This family food history is drawn from the stories I remember being told by my parents, Oliver Schafer and Harriet (Oehler) Schafer, along with memories shared by our extended family. Our family has been involved in producing, preparing, and sharing food for centuries. The Oehler family originally came from Bavaria (southern Germany) to the United States in the mid-1800s. The name “Oehler” means to produce or deal in oil—likely rendering oil from animals such as cattle, pigs, geese, and chickens, and selling it to others. How the Oehlers found their way to southern Minnesota, I do not yet know, but I hope to learn more someday. Gottfried Oehler and his wife Mary (who was from Switzerland) ran a general store in Wells, Minnesota in the 1870s. Their son Edward (born 1875\) later farmed near Buffalo Lake with his second wife Minnie Willmert. They raised two daughters, Adelia and Harriet Wilma. Harriet often told how special it was as a child to receive an orange, an apple, peanuts, and hand-knit mittens at Christmas. Oyster stew was a cherished holiday meal. Like most rural families in the early 1900s, the Oehlers maintained large gardens and spent countless hours drying and canning fruits and vegetables. Eggs and chickens were central to both their diet and livelihood. Sundays were set apart. Minnie would take the girls to church, while Edward sometimes stayed home to cook Sunday dinner. Afternoons were for visiting or picnics—often at Lake Preston, where Minnie fished and packed picnic lunches. These outings helped shape Harriet’s lifelong love of picnics and prepared her for years of cleaning and cooking fish alongside Oliver, an avid fisherman. The Schafer family immigrated from northern Germany in the mid-1800s, eventually settling near Sherburne, Minnesota. “Schafer” means shepherd, reflecting generations of farming roots. John Daniel “JD” Schafer and Dora Finke raised eleven children on the farm south of Buffalo Lake. Oliver, born in 1915, was the tenth. Oliver shared fond memories of farm life—horses named Pet and Patty, walking to a one-room schoolhouse, orchards of apples and plums, and sisters drying fruit on screens on the porch roof. Cornmeal mush with sorghum syrup was a breakfast staple, a food he loved his entire life. Harriet and Oliver married in 1935 and weathered the Depression years together. They raised cattle, hogs, chickens, and crops, creating a true farm-to-table life. Harriet ran a serious egg business, delivering eggs to “The Hatchery” on Main Street and keeping her own earnings. The kitchen, garden, chicken house, feedlot, and local lakes supplied nearly everything she cooked. Harriet was an exceptional farm cook. She made nearly everything from scratch, using ingredients fresh from her garden, her canner, or her freezer. The recipes in this book are not just instructions—they are a record of the work, resilience, and love that sustained our family across generations. Recipe Index (Alphabetical) B
